speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says that only someone who has never been hurt can mock the pain of others. He sees Juliet at her window and compares her to the sun rising in the east, urging her to outshine the pale, envious moon. He tells her not to remain a virgin servant of the moon, whose greenish garb is worn only by fools. He wishes she knew he was there, and though she is silent, her eyes speak. He imagines her eyes are like stars that have swapped places with the real stars, and her cheek is so bright it would outshine them. He longs to be the glove on her hand so he could touch her cheek.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet sighs, expressing sadness or longing.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo urges her to speak again, calling her a bright angel as glorious as a heavenly messenger appears to mortals gazing upward.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet wonders why Romeo must be Romeo, a Montague. She asks him to deny his family name, or swear his love so she can stop being a Capulet.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks himself whether he should keep listening or speak now.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet says only his name is her enemy; he would still be himself without it. A name is just a convention—a rose by any other name would smell as sweet, and Romeo without his title would still be perfect. She asks him to give up his name and take her in exchange.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo agrees to her offer: if she calls him her love, he will abandon his name and be newly baptized.

speaker: JULIET
content: Startled, Juliet asks who is hidden in the dark and has overheard her private thoughts.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says he doesn’t know how to identify himself because his name is hateful to him since it is an enemy to her; he wishes he could destroy it if it were written.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet recognizes his voice after only a few words and asks if he is Romeo, a Montague.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says he is neither if she dislikes either.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet asks how and why he came, noting the high orchard walls and the danger of death if her relatives find him.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says love gave him wings to fly over the walls; stone barriers can’t keep love out, and love dares to do anything, so her kinsmen are no obstacle.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet warns that if her family sees him, they will kill him.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo replies that more danger lies in her angry look than in twenty of their swords; if she looks kindly on him, he is protected from their hatred.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet says she would not want them to see him there for anything in the world.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He says the darkness conceals him from his enemies, and unless she loves him, he would rather they find and kill him than live without her love. 'Prorogued' means postponed, and 'wanting' means lacking. This shows his reckless passion and willingness to die for love.

speaker: JULIET
content: She asks how he discovered her location, showing surprise and caution.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He claims love guided him, giving advice while he provided sight. Though not a sailor, he would travel to the farthest shore for her, comparing her to precious 'merchandise.' This uses metaphor to express his devotion.

speaker: JULIET
content: She is glad the night hides her blush, since she has spoken so openly. She would prefer to be formal and deny her words, but abandons etiquette. She worries that if he swears love, he might be lying, as lovers' false oaths were said to amuse Jove. She admits she has been too forward but promises to be truer than those who play hard to get. She asks pardon, saying her passion was revealed unintentionally and should not be seen as shallow. 'Fain' means gladly, 'compliment' means formal manners, 'perjuries' are false oaths, 'light' means promiscuous, and 'discovered' means revealed. This speech reveals her internal conflict between passion and propriety.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He begins to swear his love by the moon, a traditional romantic oath.

speaker: JULIET
content: She interrupts, warning him not to swear by the inconstant moon, lest his love prove equally changeable.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He asks what he should swear by instead.

speaker: JULIET
content: She tells him not to swear at all, or if he must, to swear by himself, whom she worships like a god. 'Idolatry' means worship of an idol. This elevates him to a divine status in her eyes.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He starts to swear by his heart's love, but she cuts him off.

speaker: JULIET
content: She stops him, saying though she delights in him, their vows feel too hasty and sudden, like lightning that vanishes instantly. She hopes their love will grow like a bud into a flower with time. She bids good night, wishing him as much peace as she feels. 'Unadvis'd' means ill-considered. This shows her practical fear that their rush may endanger their love's future.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He asks if she will leave him without fulfillment.

speaker: JULIET
content: She asks what fulfillment he could possibly have tonight.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He wants the exchange of their faithful vows of love.

speaker: JULIET
content: She says she already gave her love before he asked, yet wishes she could give it again.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He asks if she would take it back, and for what reason.

speaker: JULIET
content: She explains she only wants to be generous and give it again. Her love is as limitless as the sea; the more she gives, the more she has. Hearing the Nurse call, she hastily says she will return and asks him to be true. 'Frank' means generous, and 'bounty' means generosity. This expresses the infinite, reciprocal nature of her love amid practical interruption.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He fears this perfect night is only a dream, too wonderful to be real. This shows his disbelief at his sudden happiness.

speaker: JULIET
content: She says if his love is honorable and intends marriage, he should send word tomorrow about when and where the ceremony will be; she will then entrust her entire life to him and follow him anywhere. This speech advances the plot by proposing a secret marriage.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse calls from offstage, interrupting the lovers.

speaker: JULIET
content: She says she will come soon, but warns him that if his intentions are not good, he should stop pursuing her and let her grieve.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse calls again, increasing the urgency.

speaker: JULIET
content: She says she is coming right away and tells him to end his effort and leave her to her sorrow, promising to send a message tomorrow.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He swears by his soul’s welfare, an expression of his sincere devotion.

speaker: JULIET
content: She bids him good night a thousand times as she exits.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He says it is worse to be without her light. Lovers going to each other are as eager as schoolboys leaving books, but parting from each other is as sad as going to school. This metaphor contrasts the joy of union with the sorrow of separation.

speaker: JULIET
content: She quietly calls him back, wishing for a falconer’s voice to call her 'tassel-gentle' (male falcon, meaning Romeo) back. She says her situation makes her speak softly, or else she would shout his name until Echo’s voice grew hoarse. This shows her longing and the constraints of their secrecy.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He says his soul is calling his name, and lovers’ voices at night sound sweet and musical.

speaker: JULIET
content: She says his name.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He responds affectionately.

speaker: JULIET
content: She asks what time tomorrow she should send someone to him.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He says by nine o’clock.

speaker: JULIET
content: She promises not to fail and says the wait will feel like twenty years; then she admits she has forgotten why she called him back, showing her distracted, lovesick state.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says he will remain there until she recalls her love for him, showing his reluctance to leave.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet playfully replies that she would keep forgetting, just so he would stay, because she loves his presence so much.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo continues the playful exchange, saying he would stay so she keeps forgetting, and he would forget any home but hers.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet notes it is nearly morning and wants him to leave, but only as far as a spoiled child’s pet bird—letting it go a little but pulling it back with a silk thread, jealous of its freedom. 'Wanton' means playful or spoiled; 'gyves' are shackles.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo wishes he were that bird, showing his desire to be close to her even if restrained.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet says she wishes the same, but fears she would kill him with too much affection. She bids good night, calling their parting a sweet sorrow, and says she will keep saying good night until morning.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo wishes sleep and peace for her, then says he wishes he were sleep and peace to rest with her. He will go to his confessor Friar Laurence for help and to tell of his good fortune. 'Ghostly Sire' means spiritual father; 'hap' means luck or fortune.
